questions.text: Why does increasing X-ray photon energy generally reduce image contrast between soft tissues?

options.A: Higher energy photons increase photoelectric absorption differences
options.B: Higher energy photons reduce Compton scattering
options.C: Higher energy photons reduce differential attenuation
options.D: Higher energy photons increase detector efficiency

questions.explanation: From the slides on interaction with matter: image contrast arises from differences in attenuation. At higher energies, attenuation coefficients of different soft tissues become more similar, reducing contrast.

questions.text: Why is photoelectric absorption more useful than Compton scattering for generating image contrast in medical X-ray imaging?

options.B: Photoelectric absorption correlates with electron density
options.C: Compton scattering dominates at low energies

questions.explanation: Slide "Physics — Photoelectric absorption": "Correlates with the electron density. Thus the more dense the material the stronger the absorption." This density dependence creates contrast between tissues.

questions.text: Why does bone appear bright in X-ray images while air appears dark?

options.A: Bone emits X-rays while air absorbs them
options.B: Bone causes Compton scattering while air causes absorption
options.C: Bone has higher electron density leading to stronger absorption

questions.explanation: Slide "Physics — Photoelectric absorption": "Bones absorb more X-rays – soft tissue absorb less." Air absorbs almost none, so many photons reach the detector.

questions.text: Why are rotating anodes necessary in modern X-ray tubes?

options.C: To distribute heat over a larger surface

questions.explanation: Slide "Physics — Modern tubes": "The anode degrades over time. Thus, modern tubes use line focus cathodes and rotating anodes." Rotation spreads heat and reduces damage.

questions.text: Why can photon-counting detectors filter out electronic noise more effectively than energy-integrating detectors?

options.A: They integrate over longer exposure times
options.B: They measure phase instead of intensity
options.C: They apply an energy threshold per photon

questions.explanation: Slide "Photon counting detectors": "Energy of each photon is recorded – Allows to filter out electronic noise." Noise events typically fall below the energy threshold.

questions.text: Why are energy-integrating detectors unable to provide spectral information?

options.B: They sum all photon energies together

questions.explanation: Slide "Energy integrating detectors": "Intensity reflects the integrated energy of all photons over a certain amount of time." Individual photon energies are lost.

questions.text: Why were early phase-contrast X-ray imaging methods impractical for clinical use?
questions.explanation: Slide "Phase-contrast X-ray imaging": "Classic approaches require a synchrotron and monochromatic X-rays." This limited clinical feasibility.

questions.text: What physical phenomenon does dark-field X-ray imaging primarily measure?
questions.explanation: Slide "Dark-field signal": dark-field imaging is sensitive to "small-angle scattering" from unresolved microstructures.

questions.text: Why does Beer–Lambert law form the mathematical basis of CT reconstruction?

options.A: It models phase shifts in X-rays
options.B: It relates attenuation to path integrals
options.D: It applies only to visible light

questions.explanation: Slides "Mathematics — Interaction with matter": attenuation is expressed as an integral of linear attenuation coefficients along a path, which is exactly what CT reconstructs.

questions.text: Why is Compton scattering problematic for image quality?

options.B: It removes photons from the beam direction

questions.explanation: From the interaction slides: Compton scattering is inelastic and deflects photons, causing them to reach the detector at incorrect positions, reducing image contrast.

questions.text: Why can phase-contrast imaging reveal structures invisible in absorption-based X-ray images?

options.A: Phase effects are stronger in dense materials
options.B: Phase changes occur even when absorption differences are small

questions.explanation: Slide "Phase-contrast X-ray imaging": "Electromagnetic waves have more properties than just intensity – Waves also have a phase." Phase variations can be detected even when absorption is weak.
